message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Improving the SMT Proof Reconstruction Pipeline in Isabelle/HOL
Paper Abstract: Sledgehammer is a tool that increases the level of automation in the Isabelle/HOL proof assistant by asking external automatic theorem provers (ATPs), including SMT solvers, to prove the current goal. When the external ATP succeeds it must provide enough evidence that the goal holds for Isabelle to be able to reprove it internally based on that evidence. In particular, Isabelle can do this by replaying fine-grained proof certificates from proof-producing SMT solvers as long as they are expressed in the Alethe format, which until now was supported only by the veriT SMT solver. We report on our experience adding proof reconstruction support for the cvc5 SMT solver in Isabelle by extending cvc5 to produce proofs in the Alethe format and then adapting Isabelle to reconstruct those proofs. We discuss several difficulties and pitfalls we encountered and describe a set of tools and techniques we developed to improve the process. A notable outcome of this effort is that Isabelle can now be used as an independent proof checker for SMT problems written in the SMT-LIB standard. We evaluate cvc5’s integration on a set of SMT-LIB benchmarks originating from Isabelle as well as on a set of Isabelle proofs. Our results confirm that this integration complements and improves Sledgehammer’s capabilities.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here's a comprehensive overview of SMT solvers and satisfiability modulo theories:

## What is SMT?

Satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) is the problem of determining whether a mathematical formula is satisfiable.(no content)It generalizes the Boolean satisfiability problem (SAT) to more complex formulas involving real numbers, integers, and/or various data structures such as lists, arrays, bit vectors, and strings.

## How It Works

SMT solvers are tools that aim to solve the SMT problem for a practical subset of inputs.(no content)The algorithm works by transforming an SMT problem into a SAT formula where atoms are replaced with Boolean variables. The algorithm repeatedly finds a satisfying valuation for the SAT problem, consults a theory solver to check consistency under the domain-specific theory, and then refines the SAT formula with this information if a contradiction is found.

## Applications

SMT solvers such as Z3 and cvc5 have been used as a building block for a wide range of applications across computer science, including in automated theorem proving, program analysis, program verification, and software testing.

## Key Solvers

Notable SMT solvers include:
- Z3, also known as the Z3 Theorem Prover, is a satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) solver developed by Microsoft.
- Cooperating Validity Checker (CVC) is a family of satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) solvers.

## Computational Complexity

Since Boolean satisfiability is already NP-complete, the SMT problem is typically NP-hard, and for many theories it is undecidable.

Web search results for query: "cvc5 SMT solver"

Links: [{"title":"Cooperating Validity Checker - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperating_Validity_Checker"},{"title":"Satisfiability modulo theories - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satisfiability_modulo_theories"},{"title":"SAT solver - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAT_solver"},{"title":"Quadratically constrained quadratic program - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadratically_constrained_quadratic_program"},{"title":"Concorde TSP Solver - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concorde_TSP_Solver"},{"title":"Five-choice serial-reaction time task - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Five-choice_serial-reaction_time_task"},{"title":"Continuously variable slope delta modulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuously_variable_slope_delta_modulation"},{"title":"Computation of cyclic redundancy checks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computation_of_cyclic_redundancy_checks"},{"title":"NL5 circuit simulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NL5_Circuit_Simulator"},{"title":"Continuously variable transmission - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuously_variable_transmission"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about cvc5:

cvc5 is part of the Cooperating Validity Checker (CVC) family of satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) solvers.(no content)CVC5 (stylized as cvc5) is one of the latest major versions, with CVC4 being the previous main version.

**Key Features:**

Both CVC4 and cvc5 support the SMT-LIB and TPTP input formats for solving SMT problems, and the SyGuS-IF format for program synthesis.(no content)cvc5 can output proofs in LFSC, Alethe, and Lean 4 formats.(no content)cvc5 has bindings for C++, Python, and Java.(no content)cvc5 additionally supports finite fields.

**Capabilities:**

In addition to standard SMT and SyGuS solving, cvc5 supports abductive reasoning, which is the problem of constructing a formula B that can be conjoined with a formula A to prove a goal formula C.

**Applications:**

SMT solvers such as Z3 and cvc5 have been used as a building block for a wide range of applications across computer science, including in automated theorem proving, program analysis, program verification, and software testing.

## Automatic Theorem Prover - Search Results

Here are the key findings about automatic theorem provers:

### Definition and Overview

First-order theorem proving is one of the most mature subfields of automated theorem proving. The logic is expressive enough to allow the specification of arbitrary problems, often in a reasonably natural and intuitive way. On the other hand, it is still semi-decidable, and a number of sound and complete calculi have been developed, enabling fully automated systems.

### Capabilities and Limitations

Since the proofs generated by automated theorem provers are typically very large, the problem of proof compression is crucial, and various techniques aiming at making the prover's output smaller, and consequently more easily understandable and checkable, have been developed.(no content)Interactive provers are used for a variety of tasks, but even fully automatic systems have proved a number of interesting and hard theorems, including at least one that has eluded human mathematicians for a long time, namely the Robbins conjecture.

### Applications

AMD, Intel and others use automated theorem proving to verify that division and other operations are correctly implemented in their processors.(no content)Other uses of theorem provers include program synthesis, constructing programs that satisfy a formal specification.

### Notable Systems

Some important automatic theorem provers include:

- Prover9 is an automated theorem prover for first-order and equational logic developed by William McCune.
- SPASS is an automated theorem prover for first-order logic with equality developed at the Max Planck Institute for Computer Science and using the superposition calculus.
- Vampire is an automatic theorem prover for first-order classical logic developed in the Department of Computer Science at the University of Manchester.
- E is a high-performance theorem prover for full first-order logic with equality. It is based on the equational superposition calculus and uses a purely equational paradigm.

Links: [{"title":"Automated theorem proving - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_theorem_proving"},{"title":"Proof assistant - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proof_assistant"},{"title":"Automated reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_reasoning"},{"title":"Nqthm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nqthm"},{"title":"SPASS - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SPASS"},{"title":"Prover9 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prover9"},{"title":"E (theorem prover) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E_(theorem_prover)"},{"title":"Category:Automated theorem proving - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Automated_theorem_proving"},{"title":"Vampire (theorem prover) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vampire_(theorem_prover)"},{"title":"Theorem prover - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theorem_prover"}]

## Automatic Theorem Prover - Search Results

Here are the key findings about automatic theorem provers:

### Definition and Overview

First-order theorem proving is one of the most mature subfields of automated theorem proving. The logic is expressive enough to allow the specification of arbitrary problems, often in a reasonably natural and intuitive way. On the other hand, it is still semi-decidable, and a number of sound and complete calculi have been developed, enabling fully automated systems.

### Capabilities and Limitations

Since the proofs generated by automated theorem provers are typically very large, the problem of proof compression is crucial, and various techniques aiming at making the prover's output smaller, and consequently more easily understandable and checkable, have been developed.(no content)Interactive provers are used for a variety of tasks, but even fully automatic systems have proved a number of interesting and hard theorems, including at least one that has eluded human mathematicians for a long time, namely the Robbins conjecture.

### Applications

AMD, Intel and others use automated theorem proving to verify that division and other operations are correctly implemented in their processors.(no content)Other uses of theorem provers include program synthesis, constructing programs that satisfy a formal specification.

### Notable Systems

Some important automatic theorem provers include:

- Prover9 is an automated theorem prover for first-order and equational logic developed by William McCune.
- SPASS is an automated theorem prover for first-order logic with equality developed at the Max Planck Institute for Computer Science and using the superposition calculus.
- Vampire is an automatic theorem prover for first-order classical logic developed in the Department of Computer Science at the University of Manchester.
- E is a high-performance theorem prover for full first-order logic with equality. It is based on the equational superposition calculus and uses a purely equational paradigm.

Web search results for query: "Isabelle proof assistant"

Links: [{"title":"Isabelle (proof assistant) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isabelle_(proof_assistant)"},{"title":"Proof assistant - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proof_assistant"},{"title":"Category:Proof assistants - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Proof_assistants"},{"title":"HOL (proof assistant) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HOL_(proof_assistant)"},{"title":"Isabel (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isabel_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Isabelle (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isabelle_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Lean (proof assistant) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lean_(proof_assistant)"},{"title":"Isabelle (Animal Crossing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isabelle_(Animal_Crossing)"},{"title":"An American Girl: Isabelle Dances Into the Spotlight - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/An_American_Girl:_Isabelle_Dances_Into_the_Spotlight"},{"title":"Isabel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isabell"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about Isabelle proof assistant:

## Overview

Isabelle is an interactive theorem prover, successor of HOL.(no content)The logic used in HOL provers is closely related to Isabelle/HOL, the most widely used logic of Isabelle.

## Key Features

Though interactive, Isabelle features efficient automatic reasoning tools, such as a term rewriting engine and a tableaux prover, various decision procedures, and, through the Sledgehammer proof-automation interface, external satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) solvers and resolution-based automated theorem provers.(no content)Isar ("intelligible semi-automated reasoning") is Isabelle's formal proof language. It is inspired by the Mizar system.(no content)Isabelle allows proofs to be written in two different styles, the procedural and the declarative. Declarative proofs (supported by Isabelle's proof language, Isar) specify the actual mathematical operations to be performed, and are therefore more easily read and checked by humans.

## Applications and Notable Achievements

Isabelle has been used to formalize numerous theorems from mathematics and computer science, like Gödel's completeness theorem, Gödel's theorem about the consistency of the axiom of choice, the prime number theorem, correctness of security protocols, and properties of programming language semantics.(no content)In 2009, the L4.verified project at NICTA produced the first formal proof of functional correctness of a general-purpose operating system kernel: the seL4 (secure embedded L4) microkernel. The proof is constructed and checked in Isabelle/HOL and comprises over 200,000 lines of proof script to verify 7,500 lines of C.

## Competitiveness

As of September 2025, only six systems have formalized proofs of more than 70% of the theorems, namely Isabelle, HOL Light, Lean, Rocq, Metamath and Mizar.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the SMT-LIB standard:

The SMT-LIB standard is the most prominent standardized interface to SMT solvers, which provides a language based on S-expressions.(no content)The SMT-LIB format comes with a number of standardized benchmarks and has enabled a yearly competition between SMT solvers called SMT-COMP.(no content)Initially, the competition took place during the Computer Aided Verification conference (CAV), but as of 2020 the competition is hosted as part of the SMT Workshop, which is affiliated with the International Joint Conference on Automated Reasoning (IJCAR).

In broader context, SMT-LIB is used to communicate with SMT solvers (Satisfiability Modulo Theories solvers), which are tools designed to determine whether mathematical formulas involving real numbers, integers, and data structures are satisfiable. Many SMT solvers marked as compatible with SMT-LIB may support only older versions of SMT-LIB, or offer only partial support for the language.

Links: [{"title":"Sledgehammer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sledgehammer"},{"title":"Sledgehammer (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sledgehammer_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Sledge Hammer! - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sledge_Hammer!"},{"title":"Automated theorem proving - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_theorem_proving"},{"title":"Sledgehammer Games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sledgehammer_Games"},{"title":"Sledgehammer (Peter Gabriel song) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sledgehammer_(Peter_Gabriel_song)"},{"title":"List of Sledge Hammer! episodes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Sledge_Hammer!_episodes"},{"title":"Sledgehammer (alleged coup plan) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sledgehammer_(alleged_coup_plan)"},{"title":"Sledge Hammer (ride) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sledge_Hammer_(ride)"},{"title":"Slide hammer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slide_hammer"}]

The search results mention Sledgehammer (Isabelle), a tool of the Isabelle proof assistant, but don't provide detailed information about it. Let me search more specifically for information about Sledgehammer in the Isabelle proof assistant context.

Links: [{"title":"Isabelle (proof assistant) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isabelle_(proof_assistant)"},{"title":"Proof assistant - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proof_assistant"},{"title":"Sledgehammer (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sledgehammer_(song)?oldformat=true"},{"title":"HOL (proof assistant) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HOL_(proof_assistant)"},{"title":"Lean (proof assistant) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lean_(proof_assistant)"},{"title":"Category:Proof assistants - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Proof_assistants"},{"title":"Sledgehammer Games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sledgehammer_Games"},{"title":"Sledge Hammer! - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sledge_Hammer!"},{"title":"Sledgehammer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sledgehammer"},{"title":"Sledgehammer (film) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sledgehammer_(film)"}]

Based on the search results, I have found good information about Sledgehammer in the context of proof automation. Here are the key findings:

## Sledgehammer Proof Automation

Sledgehammer is a proof-automation interface that enables Isabelle, a theorem prover, to integrate external satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) solvers (including CVC4) and resolution-based automated theorem provers (ATPs), such as E, SPASS, and Vampire.

The Metis proof method reconstructs resolution proofs generated by these ATPs, which helps integrate results from external automated theorem provers back into Isabelle's proof system.

Sledgehammer is part of Isabelle's broader proof automation capabilities. Though Isabelle is interactive, it features efficient automatic reasoning tools, such as a term rewriting engine and a tableaux prover, various decision procedures, and the Sledgehammer proof-automation interface.

In essence, Sledgehammer serves as a bridge between Isabelle (an interactive theorem prover) and powerful external automated reasoning tools, allowing users to leverage multiple proof automation engines to help find proofs more efficiently.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "proof checker formal verification"

Links: [{"title":"Formal verification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_verification"},{"title":"Proof assistant - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proof_assistant"},{"title":"Compiler correctness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compiler_correctness"},{"title":"Automated theorem proving - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_theorem_proving"},{"title":"Formal methods - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_methods"},{"title":"Computer-assisted proof - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer-assisted_proof"},{"title":"Model checking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_checking"},{"title":"Certifying algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Certifying_algorithm"},{"title":"Mizar system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mizar_system"},{"title":"Proof-carrying code - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proof-carrying_code"}]

Here are the search results for "proof checker formal verification":

## Overview

In the context of hardware and software systems, formal verification is the act of proving or disproving the correctness of a system with respect to a certain formal specification or property, using formal methods of mathematics.

## Proof Checkers

A proof checker is a tool that verifies the proof, which, because it is much simpler than a proof-finder, is less likely to contain errors.(no content)One way of verifying computer-aided proofs is to generate their reasoning steps in a machine readable form, and then use a proof checker program to demonstrate their correctness. Since validating a given proof is much easier than finding a proof, the checker program is simpler than the original assistant program, and it is correspondingly easier to gain confidence into its correctness.

## Key Tools and Methods

Formal verification consists of generating from the system and its specifications a collection of mathematical proof obligations, the truth of which imply conformance of the system to its specification, and discharging these obligations using either proof assistants (such as HOL, ACL2, Isabelle, Rocq, or PVS), or automatic theorem provers, including satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) solvers.(no content)A proof assistant or interactive theorem prover is a software tool to assist with the development of formal proofs by human–machine collaboration. This involves some sort of interactive proof editor, or other interface, with which a human can guide the search for proofs, the details of which are stored in, and some steps provided by, a computer.

## Applications

Formal verification is used by most or all leading hardware companies, but its use in the software industry is still languishing. This could be attributed to the greater need in the hardware industry, where errors have greater commercial significance.

Formal verification consists of generating from the system and its specifications a collection of mathematical proof obligations, the truth of which imply conformance of the system to its specification, and discharging these obligations using either proof assistants (such as HOL, ACL2, Isabelle, Rocq, or PVS), or automatic theorem provers, including satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) solvers.(no content)A proof assistant or interactive theorem prover is a software tool to assist with the development of formal proofs by human–machine collaboration. This involves some sort of interactive proof editor, or other interface, with which a human can guide the search for proofs, the details of which are stored in, and some steps provided by, a computer.

## Applications

Formal verification is used by most or all leading hardware companies, but its use in the software industry is still languishing. This could be attributed to the greater need in the hardware industry, where errors have greater commercial significance.

In the context of hardware and software systems, formal verification is the act of proving or disproving the correctness of a system with respect to a certain formal specification or property, using formal methods of mathematics.

## Proof Checkers

A proof checker is a tool that verifies the proof, which, because it is much simpler than a proof-finder, is less likely to contain errors.(no content)One way of verifying computer-aided proofs is to generate their reasoning steps in a machine readable form, and then use a proof checker program to demonstrate their correctness. ## Applications

message_text:
Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Improving the SMT Proof Reconstruction Pipeline in Isabelle/HOL". Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Type:** Contribution

The paper is classified as a contribution because it:
- Proposes new proof reconstruction support for the cvc5 SMT solver
- Extends cvc5 to produce proofs in the Alethe format
- Develops new tools and techniques for proof reconstruction
- Demonstrates that Isabelle can now be used as an independent proof checker

## Extracted Triples

The analysis identified 5 key technologies and methodologies:

1. **Isabelle (proof assistant)** - Artifact - Uses
   - The core proof assistant platform extended by this work

2. **Automated theorem proving** - Method - Uses
   - The external reasoning techniques integrated via Sledgehammer

3. **Satisfiability modulo theories** - Concept - Uses
   - The SMT solver technology that is central to the work

4. **Cooperating Validity Checker (cvc5)** - Artifact - Proposes
   - The SMT solver extended in this paper to support Alethe format proofs

5. **Formal verification** - Task - Uses
   - The broader application domain enabled by improved proof automation

All triples have been validated with correct Wikipedia URLs, proper entity types, and clear relevance statements. The validation script confirms all checks passed successfully.

Sources:
- [Isabelle (proof assistant)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isabelle_(proof_assistant))
- [Automated theorem proving](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_theorem_proving)
- [Satisfiability modulo theories](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satisfiability_modulo_theories)
- [Cooperating Validity Checker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperating_Validity_Checker)
- [Formal verification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_verification)
